author: Tanveer Mann
title: Sister’s heartbreaking letter to park asking why there are no swings for her disabled brother
text:
Naomi, 8, wrote a letter to the ‘park builder’s asking why there were no swings for her disabled twin brother Isaac (Picture: Miriam Gwynne) An eight-year-old girl has written a heartbreaking letter to her local park asking them why there are no swings for her disabled twin brother. 
This is what the Tube map looks like for a disabled person Naomi and Isaac, both 8, had been eagerly awaiting the opening of the new park around the corner from their home in Lanarkshire for months.
So when it finally opened, the eight-year-olds, who are both autistic, were the first to visit the park.
Naomi explained how her brother is too big for the baby swing and can’t hold onto the bars of the grown up swing (Picture: Miriam Gwynne) The twins’ mum, Miriam Gwynne, says she thought they were having a ‘lovely time’ until Naomi, showed her a letter she had written by herself.
It read: ‘Dear park builders, I like the new park but please could you make a disabled swing for it? Isaac my twin brother is too big for a baby swing and can’t hold on to the bars of the grown up swings.
‘His favourite thing is a swing and we are both sad. Why did you forget about him?’
MORE: Man fined for parking over two spaces when no disabled bays were available 
Isaac has severe autism, neurofibromatosis, a brain tumour and severe learning difficulties (Picture: Miriam Gwynne) The twins had been looking forward to playing at the new park (Picture: Miriam Gwynne) Naomi then drew a picture of the type of swing she would like the council to introduce for her brother, who has global delay and is visually-impaired with a brain tumour so does not know how to hold onto a normal swing.
Mrs Gwynne, who is a full-time carer for her children, told Metro.co.uk : ‘I was so excited to see the council had transformed our local park and could not wait to take my twins.
Naomi with mum Miriam (Picture: Miriam Gwynne) ‘We watched from our window as it was being built and the kids were getting excited.
New website described as TripAdvisor for disabled people ‘We are now regulars there and I thought the kids were having a wonderful time until my 8 year old daughter showed me something she had written all by herself
‘I read her letter through tears as I suddenly realised she was right. Her brother who has severe autism, NF1, a brain tumour and severe learning difficulties had no swing.
‘He has no speech but her letter spoke for the both.’
@SouthLanCouncil thank you for listening to my daughter! pic.twitter.com/Hh2O2fedG3 
— Miriam Gwynne (@GwynneMiriam) March 20, 2017 

She added: ‘I am so proud of her! She has autism herself so to have though to write a letter is incredible.’
Mrs Gwynne tweeted a picture of Naomi’s letter to South Lanarkshire council on Saturday and received a response this morning.
Autistic man murdered over picture of woman jumping over statues of penises, court told It reads: ‘We try to include different pieces of inclusive play equipment in each of our play areas to offer variety.
‘We have asked the designer to look into whether the existing swing frame can incorporate a disabled seat for Isaac.
‘Thanks for letting us know about this.’
